TopicTitle: Mk2R Chute doesn't open descending Duna

Articles.Content:
Right now I descend on a quite shallow entry trajectory, dropping through 10 km height (terrain altitude) with around 830 m/s speed. I retroburn to reduce speed to 420 m/s, that is when myMk12-R Radial-Mount Drogue Chutes appear safe to deploy .

Cutting off the engines and the SAS, the drogue chutes decrease my speed below 210 m/s, which then gives a for the   Mk2-R Radial-Mount Parachute .

Activating them (to enable the needed braking to slow it to reasonable 10 or so m/s) does nothing. The chute deploy sound is audible, but neither are they visible nor does the speed decrease further as expected.

What is going on?

Welcome to the forum @Rongor. 

When you deploy the main radial chutes, what color does the staging icon change to? If it's cyan on a gray background, that means that they are armed (staged) but the current atmospheric pressure is below the pre-deploy limit. I suspect that is what's happening. Try lowering the pre-deploy pressure limit in the right click menu for the chutes. 

If that's not the issue, a screenshot of your ship when you're having the problem will go a long way towards finding the problem.

29 minutes ago, Rongor said:

Activating them (to enable the needed braking to slow it to reasonable 10 or so m/s) does nothing. The chute deploy sound is audible, but neither are they visible nor does the speed decrease further as expected.

What is going on?

Welcome to the forums!

Sounds like you have a pretty good handle on Duna lander design; drogues + regular chutes should work just fine.

If I had to guess what's going on, one possibility is that there's just not enough air pressure to activate the main chutes. A few things to check:

  • What altitude is the ground where you're trying to land?  Duna has a lot of high-elevation terrain where the air gets really thin.
  • What is the minimum deploy pressure set to on your non-deploying chutes?
  • What is the actual air pressure when you're trying to deploy them?  (You can tell this if you have a Pres-Mat Barometer and choose the right-click menu item to activate display.)

One thing about Duna lander design:  if there's any way you can incorporate some lift into it (either just good ol' fashioned body lift, or actual lift from wing-like things), that could help you quite a bit.  If you're down to 800ish m/s at 10 km altitude, you shouldn't have to spend 400 m/s of rocket power to get down to drogue speeds-- with some lift, you can just keep your altitude at 10 km and slow down to drogue speed that way.  This would allow you to save that fuel to help cushion the landing when you come down to terra firma.

A screenshot of the ship would help.

Hey guys, thanks for the replies.

I already noticed the large areas of elevation above "mean sea level" but that shouldn't be a problem because those Mk2R are set to standard which should enable them at a minimum pressure of 0.04. In the current envelope I am just surpassing 1.0 so that shouldn't be the limitation. At a former attempt, I learnt that the speed has to drop below around 210 m/s for Mk2R to be deployable. Since the Mk12 drogues manage to slow to 100 m/s, they should work.

 

This is the situation before pulling the Mk12 drogue chutes. Shown is the configuration of the Mk2 and the pressure. I already pulled that minAltitide slider up to 5000. According to the wiki, this means they should be available at 5000 AGL, which is height over ground.

This is after deploying 2 drogues, speed is well below 210, pressure is above 3, the icon in stage 3 shows "safe to deploy". This is the situation I explained in the first post. Those Mk2 in stage 3 won't deploy, only the deployment sound is audible. Thereafter the icon for them turns blue instead of a white parachute, the square remaining gray. Right clicking direct onto a Mk2 lets me switch between "disarm" (then turning grey/white again) and "deploy chute" (switching back to blue/grey but deploying nothing at all)

The barometer's readout is measured in kPa; the parachute's deploy pressure is measured in atm. 1 atm is ~101.3 kPa, so when your barometer is reading 1.25, you're at ~0.012 atm - well below the 0.04 minimum pressure you've set. The full-deploy altitude you've set doesn't matter if you aren't above the minimum pressure.

Parachuting onto Duna is tricky, because some terrain is high enough that you never reach your minimum pressure - the highlands and (apparently) the poles reach that threshold.

I see, so alike in real life, different measurement units break a mission

So I guess in this case I just have rely on engine burns then?

10 minutes ago, Rongor said:

So I guess in this case I just have rely on engine burns then?

Not necessarily. If you're feeling up to it you can open the .craft file and edit the parachutes by hand to have a lower deployment pressure.
Nah, I really aim to stick to the stuff I have at hand (stock KSP materiel)

23 minutes ago, Rongor said:

I see, so alike in real life, different measurement units break a mission

So I guess in this case I just have rely on engine burns then?

Yeah, pretty much.

The Duna highlands are difficult because of the thin air.  The highest spots are high enough that regular parachutes simply can't deploy at all.

So, some options.  Do you really need to land at 5000m? Could you pick a different landing spot, to land where it's lower than 5000m elevation on the ground?  Even a couple of kilometers lower would help a lot.

If you're set on landing at high, un-parachutable elevation:  You'll definitely need a fair amount of rocket power to land, but with attention to ship design, you can save rocket power earlier.  You already have a ship design with a reasonable amount of body lift.  As you're going through reentry, try angling your approach so you're not pointing straight retrograde, but rather tipped about 30 degrees off retrograde (with the engine high and the nose low).  This will generate body lift and help to keep your altitude high for longer, and allow you to bleed off a lot of speed without using any rocket power at all.  You should be able to get to the point where you can deploy your drogues even without using your engine at all.  (You can also help with the lift by adding some aero surfaces to the craft-- even just a little, like a couple of AV-T1 Winglets.)

You could also double the number of drogues.

Doing this should allow you to get a ship that can arrive at Duna and aerobrake to drogue-deployable speeds without using engines at all, while still at a comfortable altitude above the ground.  Then activate drogues, which will slow you down to a reasonable speed (under 100 m/s), and use your engine to retro-thrust just before landing.  That should work even in the highlands.

Yes, I am totally aiming to land somewhere deeper but those spots seem to be the minority so far. I will definitely try adding some lift(and drogue) generating parts.

 

Thank you!
